quotes: You have a right to perform your duty, but you are not entitled to the fruits of your actions [Bhagavad Gita 2.47]
Just as the soul experiences childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too it will acquire another body. The wise are not deluded by these changes [Bhagavad Gita 2.13]
The non-permanent appearance of happiness and distress, and their disappearance in due course, are like the appearance and disappearance of winter and summer seasons [Bhagavad Gita 2.14]
The soul is neither born, nor does it ever die; nor having once existed, does it cease to be. The soul is eternal, immortal, and primeval [Bhagavad Gita 2.20]
Work done as a sacrifice for the Supreme must be performed; otherwise, work causes bondage in this material world [Bhagavad Gita 3.9]
The ignorant work for the results of their actions, whereas the wise act without attachment, understanding the divine plan [Bhagavad Gita 3.27]
Whenever righteousness declines and unrighteousness prevails, O Arjuna, at that time I manifest Myself on earth [Bhagavad Gita 4.7]
To protect the righteous, to annihilate the wicked, and to re-establish dharma, I appear millennium after millennium [Bhagavad Gita 4.8]
Approach those who have realized the truth. Inquire from them with humility and serve them. They will impart knowledge to you [Bhagavad Gita 4.34]
One who performs his duty without attachment, surrendering the results to the Supreme, attains peace [Bhagavad Gita 5.10]
A person who is not disturbed by happiness and distress and remains steady in both is certainly eligible for liberation [Bhagavad Gita 2.15]
One who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is intelligent among men [Bhagavad Gita 4.18]
The mind is restless and difficult to restrain, but it is subdued by practice and detachment [Bhagavad Gita 6.35]
For one who has conquered the mind, the mind is the best of friends; but for one who has failed to do so, the mind will remain the greatest enemy [Bhagavad Gita 6.6]
Whatever action is performed by a great person, common men follow in their footsteps [Bhagavad Gita 3.21]
He who sees Me everywhere and sees everything in Me, I am never lost to him, nor is he ever lost to Me [Bhagavad Gita 6.30]
The person who is free from all attachments and whose mind is fixed on the Supreme attains eternal peace [Bhagavad Gita 5.12]
One who has renounced all desires for sense gratification, who lives free from cravings, attains peace [Bhagavad Gita 2.71]
One who sees all beings as equal, whether friend or foe, is established in wisdom [Bhagavad Gita 6.9]
There is neither this world nor the world beyond nor happiness for the one who doubts [Bhagavad Gita 4.40]
Reshape yourself through the power of your will; never let yourself be degraded by self-will [Bhagavad Gita 6.5]
Whatever happened was good. Whatever is happening is good. Whatever will happen will also be good [Bhagavad Gita 2.3]
A person is made by his belief. As he believes, so he is [Bhagavad Gita 17.3]
Perform your duty with detachment and dedication, without being driven by the desire for rewards [Bhagavad Gita 3.19]
The wise work for the welfare of the world, without thought of personal gain [Bhagavad Gita 3.25]
One should uplift oneself by one’s own mind, and not degrade oneself [Bhagavad Gita 6.5]
One who neither rejoices nor grieves, who neither laments nor desires, who has renounced both good and evil actions, is fit for liberation [Bhagavad Gita 12.17]
The mind is everything. It can make heaven out of hell and hell out of heaven [Bhagavad Gita 6.5]
A true yogi sees all beings with equal vision, whether a saint or a sinner [Bhagavad Gita 5.18]
Knowledge is better than mere practice, and meditation is better than knowledge. Renouncing the fruits of actions leads to peace [Bhagavad Gita 12.12]
By surrendering everything unto Me, you will attain divine peace [Bhagavad Gita 18.62]
No one who does good work will ever come to a bad end, either here or in the world to come [Bhagavad Gita 6.40]
One who is not envious but is a kind friend to all living entities is very dear to Me [Bhagavad Gita 12.13]
Lust, anger, and greed are the three gates to hell. Therefore, one should abandon them [Bhagavad Gita 16.21]
A person who is beyond dualities, free from attachment, attains the eternal abode [Bhagavad Gita 15.5]
The Supreme Lord is situated in everyone’s heart. Direct your mind towards Him [Bhagavad Gita 18.61]
That which seems like poison in the beginning but is nectar in the end is said to be in the mode of goodness [Bhagavad Gita 18.37]
O Arjuna, I am the taste in water, the light of the sun and moon, the sacred syllable Om in the Vedas [Bhagavad Gita 7.8]
For one who has conquered his mind, peace is near; for one who has failed to do so, peace is far away [Bhagavad Gita 6.7]
He who abandons all desires and acts free from longing, attains perfect peace [Bhagavad Gita 2.71]
I am the beginning, middle, and end of all beings [Bhagavad Gita 10.20]
One who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is truly wise [Bhagavad Gita 4.18]
Those who worship Me with love and devotion, I give them the understanding by which they can come to Me [Bhagavad Gita 10.10]
Even if one is the most sinful of sinners, one can cross over all sin by the raft of knowledge [Bhagavad Gita 4.36]
Do not be attached to success or failure. Act with focus and dedication [Bhagavad Gita 2.48]
By devotion alone can I be truly known, O Arjuna, and seen directly [Bhagavad Gita 11.54]
A yogi is greater than an ascetic, greater than a scholar, and greater than a ritualist. Therefore, be a yogi [Bhagavad Gita 6.46]
